questions.question:
Web application developers occasionally use hidden fields on web pages to save information about a client
session. This technique is used to store session variables that enable persistence across web pages, such as
maintaining the contents of a shopping cart on a retail website application. The MOST likely web-based
attack due to this practice is:

justifications.A:
Web application developers sometimes use hidden fields to save information about a client session
or to submit hidden parameters, such as the language of the end user, to the underlying application.
Because hidden form fields do not display in the browser, developers may feel safe passing
unvalidated data in the hidden fields (to be validated later). This practice is not safe because an
attacker can intercept, modify and submit requests, which can discover information or perform
functions that the web developer never intended. The malicious modification of web application
parameters is known as parameter tampering.
justifications.B:
Cross-site scripting involves the compromise of the web page to redirect users to content on the attacker
website. The use of hidden fields has no impact on the likelihood of a cross-site scripting attack because
these fields are static content that cannot ordinarily be modified to create this type of attack.
justifications.C:
Web applications use cookies to save session state information on the client machine so that the user
does not need to log on every time a page is visited. Cookie poisoning refers to the interception and
modification of session cookies to impersonate the user or steal logon credentials. The use of hidden
fields has no relation to cookie poisoning.
justifications.D:
Stealth commanding is the hijacking of a web server by the installation of unauthorized code. Although
the use of hidden forms may increase the risk of server compromise, the most common server exploits
involve vulnerabilities of the server operating system or web server.
373

questions.question: Which control is the BEST way to ensure that the data in a file have not been changed during transmission?

justifications.A:
A reasonableness check is used to ensure that input data is within expected values, not to ensure integrity
of data transmission. Data can be changed and still pass a reasonableness test.
justifications.B:
Parity bits are a weak form of data integrity checks used to detect enors in transmission, but they are not
as good as using a hash.
justifications.C:
Hash values are calculated on the file and are very sensitive to any changes in the data values in the
file. Thus, they are the best way to ensure that data has not changed.
justifications.D:
Check digits are used to detect an error in a numeric field such as an account number and is usually
related to a transposition or transcribing error.

questions.question: The PRIMARY purpose of audit trails is to:

options.C: improve the operational efficiency of the system.
options.D: provide information to auditors who want to track transactions.

justifications.A:
The objective of enabling software to provide audit trails is not to improve system efficiency, because it
often involves additional processing, which may reduce response time for users.
justifications.B:
Enabling audit trails helps in establishing the accountability and responsibility of processed
transactions by tracing transactions through the system.
justifications.C:
Enabling audit trails involves storage and, thus, occupies disk space and may decrease operational
efficiency.
justifications.D:
Audit trails are used to track transactions fbr various purposes, not just fbr audit. The use of audit trails fbr
information systems (IS) auditors is valid; however, it is not the primary reason.
374 C!SA ® Official Questions, Answers & Explanations Manual 13th Edition
©ISACA. All Rights Reserved.

questions.question:
Which of the following systems or tools can recognize that a credit card transaction is MORE likely to have
resulted from a stolen credit card than from the holder of the credit card?

justifications.A:
An intrusion detection system (IDS) is effective in detecting network or host-based enors but not
effective in measuring fraudulent transactions.
justifications.B:
Data mining is a technique used to detect trends or patterns of transactions or data. If the historical
pattern of charges against a credit card account is changed, then it is a flag that the transaction may
have resulted from a fraudulent use of the card.
justifications.C:
A firewall is an excellent tool fbr protecting networks and systems but not effective in detecting
fraudulent transactions.
justifications.D: A packet filtering router operates at a network level and cannot see a transaction.

questions.question: Which of the following BEST ensures the integrity of a server's operating system?

options.A: Protecting the server in a secure location

justifications.A:
Protecting the server in a secure location is a good practice, but it does not ensure that a user will not try
to exploit logical vulnerabilities and compromise the operating system (OS).
justifications.B:
Setting a boot password is a good practice but does not ensure that a user will not try to exploit logical
vulnerabilities and compromise the OS.
justifications.C:
Hardening a system means to configure it in the most secure manner (i.e., install latest security
patches, properly define access authorization for users and administrators, disable insecure options
and uninstall unused services) to prevent nonprivileged users from gaining the right to execute
privileged instructions and, thus, take control of the entire machine, jeopardizing the integrity of
the OS.
justifications.D:
Activity logging has two weaknesses in this scenario—it is a detective control (not a preventive one), and
the attacker who already gained privileged access can modify logs or disable them.
375

questions.question:
Which of the following network components is PRIMARILY set up to serve as a security measure by
preventing unauthorized traffic between different segments of the network?

justifications.A:
Firewall systems are the primary tool that enables an enterprise to prevent unauthorized access
between networks. An enterprise may choose to deploy one or more systems that function as
firewalls.
justifications.B:
Routers can filter packets based on parameters, such as source address, but are not primarily a security
tool.
justifications.C:
Based on Media Access Control addresses, layer 2 switches separate traffic without determining whether
it is authorized or unauthorized traffic.
justifications.D:
A virtual local area network (VLAN) is a functionality of some switches that allows them to control
traffic between different ports even though they are in the same physical local access network.
Nevertheless, they do not effectively deal with authorized versus unauthorized traffic.
376 CISA ® Official Questions, Answers & Explanations Manual 13th Edition
©ISACA. All Rights Reserved.

questions.question:
An information systems (IS) auditor discovers that the chief information officer (CIO) of an enterprise is
using a wireless broadband modem using global system for mobile communications (GSM) technology. This
modem is being used to connect the CIO's laptop to the enterprise virtual private network when the CIO
travels outside of the office. The IS auditor should:

options.A: do nothing because the inherent security features of GSM technology are appropriate.
options.B: recommend that the CIO stop using the laptop computer until encryption is enabled.
options.C:
ensure that media access control (MAC) address filtering is enabled on the network so that unauthorized
wireless users cannot connect.
options.D: suggest that multifactor authentication be used over the wireless link to prevent unauthorized

justifications.A:
The inherent security features of global system for mobile communications (GSM) technology
combined with the use of a virtual private network (VPN) are appropriate. The confidentiality of
the communication on the GSM radio link is ensured by the use of encryption, and the use of a VPN
signifies that an encrypted session is established between the laptop and the enterprise network.
GSM is a global standard for cellular telecommunications that can be used for voice and data.
Currently deployed commercial GSM technology has multiple overlapping security features that
prevent eavesdropping, session hijacking and unauthorized use of the GSM carrier network. While
other wireless technologies such as 802.11 wireless local area network (LAN) technologies have been
designed to allow the user to adjust or even disable security settings, GSM does not allow any
devices to connect to the system unless all relevant security features are active and enabled.
justifications.B:
Because the chief information officer (CIO) is using a VPN, it can be assumed that encryption is enabled
in addition to the security features in GSM. VPNs do not allow the transfer of data fbr storage on the
remote device (such as the CIO's laptop).
justifications.C:
Media access control (MAC) filtering can be used on a wireless LAN but does not apply to a GSM
network device.
justifications.D:
Because the GSM network is being used rather than a wireless LAN, it is not possible to
configure settings for multifactor authentication over the wireless link. However, in other technology
configurations, multifactor authentication is recommended because it will better protect against
unauthorized access than single-factor authentication.
377

©ISACA. All Rights Reserved.

questions.question:
Which of the following is the BEST way to minimize unauthorized access to unattended end-user PC
systems?

options.A: Enforce the use of a password-protected screen saver.
options.C: Terminate the user session at predefined intervals.
options.D: Adjust power management settings so the monitor screen is blank.

justifications.A:
A password-protected screen saver with a proper time interval is the best measure to prevent
unauthorized access to unattended end-user systems. It is important to ensure that users lock the
workstation when they step away from the machine, which is something that can be reinforced via
awareness training.
justifications.B:
There are solutions that will lock machines when users step away from their desks, and those are suitable
here; however, those tools are a more expensive solution that normally include the use of smart cards and
extra hardware. Therefore, the use of a password-protected screen saver is a better solution.
justifications.C:
Terminating user sessions is often done fbr remote login (periodic re-authentication) or after a certain
amount of inactivity on a web or server session. There is more risk related to leaving the workstation
unlocked.
justifications.D: Switching off the monitor is not a solution, because the monitor can simply be switched on.

questions.question:
An enterprise's IT director approved the installation of a wireless local area network (WLAN) access point
in a conference room for a team of consultants to access the Internet with their laptop computers. The BEST
control to protect the corporate servers from unauthorized access is to ensure that:

options.A: encryption is enabled on the access point.
options.B: the conference room network is on a separate virtual local area network (VLAN).
options.C: antivirus signatures and patch levels are current on the consultants, laptops.
options.D: default user IDs are disabled and strong passwords are set on the corporate servers.

justifications.A:
Enabling encryption is a good idea to prevent unauthorized network access, but it is more important to
isolate the consultants from the rest of the corporate network.
justifications.B:
The installation of the wireless network device presents risk to the corporate servers from
authorized and unauthorized users. A separate virtual local area network (VLAN) is the best
solution because it ensures that authorized and unauthorized users are prevented from gaining
network access to database servers, while allowing Internet access to authorized users.
justifications.C:
Antivirus signatures and patch levels are good practices but not as critical as preventing network access
via access controls fbr the enterprise's servers.
justifications.D:
Protecting the enterprise's servers through good passwords is good practice, but it is still necessary to
isolate the network being used by the consultants. If the consultants can access the rest of the network,
they can use password cracking tools against other corporate machines.

questions.question:
The information systems (IS) auditor is reviewing an enterprise's HR database implementation. The IS auditor
discovers that the database servers are clustered for high availability, all default database accounts have been
removed and database audit logs are kept and reviewed on a weekly basis. What other area should the IS
auditor check to ensure that the databases are appropriately secured?

options.A: Database administrators are restricted from access to HR data.

justifications.A:
Database administrators have access to all data on the server, but there is no practical control to prevent
that; therefore, this is not a concern.
justifications.B:
Database audit logs normally do not contain any confidential data; therefore, encrypting the log files is
not required.
justifications.C:
If a stored procedure contains a security sensitive function, such as encrypting data, it can be a
requirement to encrypt the stored procedure. However, this is less critical than ensuring initialization
parameters are correct.
justifications.D:
When a database is opened, many of its configuration options are governed by initialization
parameters. These parameters are usually governed by a file that contains many settings. The
system initialization parameters address many global database settings, including authentication,
remote access and other critical security areas. To effectively audit a database implementation, the
information systems (IS) auditor must examine the database initialization parameters.
379

questions.question:
An information systems (IS) auditor has been asked by management to review a potentially fraudulent
transaction. The PRIMARY fbcus of the IS auditor while evaluating the transaction should be to:

options.A: maintain impartiality while evaluating the transaction.
options.B: ensure that the independence of the IS auditor is maintained.
options.C: ensure that the integrity of the evidence is maintained.
options.D: assess all relevant evidence for the transaction.

justifications.A:
Although it is important for an information systems (IS) auditor to be impartial, in this case it is more
critical that the evidence be preserved.
justifications.B:
Although it is important fbr an IS auditor to maintain independence, in this case, it is more critical that the
evidence be preserved.
justifications.C:
The IS auditor has been requested to perform an investigation to capture evidence that may be used
fbr legal purposes, and, therefore, maintaining the integrity of the evidence should be the foremost
goal. Improperly handled computer evidence is subject to being ruled inadmissible in a court of law.
justifications.D:
Although it is also important to assess all relevant evidence, it is more important to maintain the chain of
custody, which ensures the integrity of evidence.

questions.question:
A new business application was designed in a large, complex enterprise, and the business owner requested
that the various reports be viewed on a need-to-know basis. Which of the following access control methods is
the BEST method to achieve this requirement?

justifications.A:
An access control system based on mandatory access control is expensive and difficult to implement and
maintain in a large complex enterprise.
justifications.B:
Role-based access control limits access according to job roles and responsibilities and is the best
method to allow only authorized users to view reports on a need-to-know basis.
justifications.C:
With discretionary access control (DAC), the owner of the resources decides who should have access to
those resources. Most access control systems are an implementation of DAC. This control is not specific
enough for this scenario.
justifications.D:
Single sign-on (SSO) is an access control technology that is used to manage access to multiple systems,
networks and applications. This control is not specific enough for this question.
380 CISA ® Official Questions, Answers & Explanations Manual 13th Edition
©ISACA. All Rights Reserved.

questions.question:
Which of the following is the BEST control to prevent the deletion of audit logs by unauthorized individuals
in an enterprise?

options.A: Actions performed on log files should be tracked in a separate log.
options.B: Write access to audit logs should be disabled.
options.C: Only select personnel should have rights to view or delete audit logs.
options.D: Backups of audit logs should be performed periodically.

justifications.A: Having additional copies of log file activity does not prevent the original log files from being deleted.
justifications.B: For servers and applications to operate correctly, write access cannot be disabled.
justifications.C:
Granting audit-log access to only system administrators and security administrators reduces the
possibility of these files being deleted.
justifications.D: Frequent backups of audit logs does not prevent the logs from being deleted.

questions.question:
An enterprise is implementing a Dynamic Host Configuration Protocol (DHCP). Which of the following
conditions represents the GREATEST concern?

options.B: A packet filtering firewall is used.
options.C: The internet protocol (IP) address space is smaller than the number of PCs.
options.D: Access to a network port is not restricted.

justifications.A: Dynamic Host Configuration Protocol (DHCP) provides convenience (an advantage) to laptop users.
justifications.B: The existence of a firewall can be a security measure and is not normally be of concern.
justifications.C:
A limited number of internet protocol (IP) addresses can be addressed through network address
translation or by increasing the number of IP addresses assigned to a particular subnet.
justifications.D:
Physical access to network ports is not restricted, allowing unauthorized individuals to connect to
the internal network.

questions.question:
Which of the following is an effective preventive control to ensure that a database administrator (DBA)
complies with the custodianship of the enterprise's data?

options.C: Review of access logs and activities

justifications.A:
Exception reports are detective controls used to indicate when the activities of the database administrator
(DBA) were performed without authorization.
justifications.B:
Adequate segregation/separation of duties (SoD) is a preventative control that can restrict the
activities of the DBA to those that have been authorized by the data owners. SoD can restrict what a
DBA can do by requiring more than one person to participate to complete a task.
justifications.C: Reviews of access logs are used to detect the activities performed by the DBA.
justifications.D:
Management supervision of DBA activities is used to detect which DBA activities were not authorized.
381
C/SA ® Official Questions, Answers & Explanations Manual 13th Edition
©ISACA. All Rights Reserved.

questions.question:
An employee received a digital photo frame as a gift and connected it to his/her work PC to transfer digital
photos. The PRIMARY risk that this scenario introduces is that:

options.A: the photo frame storage media can be used to steal enterprise data.
options.B: the drivers fbr the photo frame may be incompatible and crash the user's PC.
options.C: the employee may bring inappropriate photographs into the office.
options.D: the photo frame can be infected with malware.

justifications.A:
Although any storage device can be used to steal data, the damage caused by malware can be widespread
and severe fbr the enterprise, which is the more significant risk.
justifications.B:
Although device drivers may be incompatible and crash the user's PC, the damage caused by malware can
be widespread and severe fbr the enterprise.
justifications.C:
Although inappropriate content can result, the damage caused by malware can be widespread and severe
for the enterprise.
justifications.D:
Any storage device can be a vehicle fbr infecting other computers with malware. Some devices have
been found to be infected in the factory during the manufacturing process. Controls should exist to
prohibit employees from connecting any storage media devices to their enterprise-issued PCs.

questions.question:
An enterprise discovers that the computer of the chief financial officer has been infected with malware that
includes a keystroke logger and a rootkit. The FIRST action to take is to:

options.A: contact the appropriate law enforcement authorities to begin an investigation.
options.B: immediately ensure that no additional data are compromised.
options.C: disconnect the PC from the network.
options.D: update the antivirus signature on the PC to ensure that the malware or virus is detected and removed.

justifications.A:
Although contacting law enforcement may be needed, the first step is to halt data flow by disconnecting
the computer from the network.
justifications.B:
The first step is to disconnect the computer from the network, thus ensuring that no additional data are
compromised. Then, using proper forensic techniques, capture the information stored in temporary files,
network connection information, programs loaded into memory and other information on the machine.
justifications.C:
The most important task is to prevent further data compromise and preserve evidence by
disconnecting the computer from the network.
justifications.D:
Preserve the machine in a forensically sound condition and do not make any changes to it except to
disconnect it from the network. Otherwise, evidence would be destroyed by powering off the PC or
updating the software on the PC. Information stored in temporary files, network connection information,
programs loaded into memory and other information may be lost.
382 C/SA ® Official Questions, Answers & Explanations Manual 13th Edition
©ISACA. All Rights Reserved.

questions.question:
The information systems (IS) auditor is reviewing findings from a prior IS audit of a hospital. One finding
indicates that the organization was using email to communicate sensitive patient issues. The IT manager
indicates that to address this finding, the organization has implemented digital signatures fbr all email users.
What should the IS auditor's response be?

options.A: Digital signatures are not adequate to protect confidentiality.
options.B: Digital signatures are adequate to protect confidentiality.
options.C: The IS auditor should gather more information about the specific implementation.
options.D: The IS auditor should recommend implementation of digital watermarking fbr secure email.

justifications.A:
Digital signatures are designed to provide authentication and nonrepudiation for email and other
transmissions but are not adequate fbr confidentiality. This implementation is not adequate to
address the prior year's finding.
justifications.B:
Digital signatures do not encrypt message contents; therefore, an attacker who intercepts a message can
read the message.
justifications.C:
Although gathering additional information is always a good step before drawing a conclusion on a
finding, in this case, the implemented solution does not provide confidentiality.
justifications.D:
Digital watermarking is used to protect intellectual property rights fbr documents rather than to protect the
confidentiality of email.

questions.question: Which of the following line media would provide the BEST security for a telecommunication network?

justifications.A:
The secure use of broadband communications is subject to whether the network is shared with other users,
the data are encrypted and the risk of network interruption.
justifications.B:
A baseband network is one that is usually shared with many other users and requires encryption of traffic
but still may allow some traffic analysis by an attacker.
justifications.C:
A dial-up line is fairly secure because it is a private connection, but it is too slow to be considered for
most commercial applications today.
justifications.D:
Dedicated lines are set apart for a particular user or organization. Because there is no sharing
of lines or intermediate entry points, the risk of interception or disruption of telecommunications
messages is lower
383

questions.question:
To ensure that an enterprise is complying with privacy requirements, an information systems (IS) auditor
should FIRST review:

options.D: adherence to organizational policies, standards and procedures.

justifications.A:
To comply with requirements, the information systems (IS) auditor must first know what the requirements
are. They can vary from one jurisdiction to another. The IT infrastructure is related to the implementation
of the requirements.
justifications.B:
The policies of the enterprise are subject to the legal requirements and should be checked fbr compliance
after the legal requirements are reviewed.
justifications.C:
To ensure that the enterprise is complying with privacy issues, an IS auditor should address legal
and regulatory requirements first. To comply with legal and regulatory requirements, enterprises
need to adopt the appropriate infrastructure. After understanding the legal and regulatory
requirements, an IS auditor should evaluate organizational policies, standards and procedures
to determine whether they adequately address the privacy requirements, and then review the
adherence to these specific policies, standards and procedures.
justifications.D:
Checking for compliance is only done after the IS auditor is assured that the policies, standards and
procedures are aligned with the legal requirements.

questions.question:
A human resources enterprise offers wireless Internet access to its guests, after authenticating with a generic
user ID and password. The generic ID and password are requested from the reception desk. Which of the
following controls BEST addresses the situation?

options.A: The password fbr the wireless network is changed on a weekly basis.
options.B: A stateful inspection firewall is used between the public wireless and enterprise networks.
options.C: The public wireless network is physically segregated from the enterprise network.
options.D: An intrusion detection system is deployed within the wireless network.

justifications.A:
Changing the password for the wireless network does not secure against unauthorized access to the
enterprise network, especially because a guest can gain access to the wireless local area network at any
time prior to the weekly password change interval.
justifications.B:
A stateful inspection firewall will screen all packets from the wireless network into the enterprise
network; however, the configuration of the firewall needs to be audited and firewall compromises,
although unlikely, are possible.
justifications.C:
Keeping the wireless network physically separate from the enterprise network is the best way to
secure the enterprise network from intrusion.
justifications.D:
An intrusion detection system will detect intrusions but will not prevent unauthorized individuals from
accessing the network.
384 CISA ® Official Questions, Answers & Explanations Manual 13th Edition
©ISACA. All Rights Reserved.

questions.question:
When reviewing the implementation of a local area network, an information systems (IS) auditor should
FIRST review the:

justifications.A: Verification of nodes from the node list follows the review of the network diagram.
justifications.B: The review of the acceptance test report follows the verification of nodes from the node list.
justifications.C:
To properly review a local area network implementation, an information systems (IS) auditor
should first verify the network diagram to identify risk or single points of failure.
justifications.D: The users list is reviewed after the acceptance test report.

questions.question:
An information systems (IS) auditor discovers that the configuration settings fbr password controls are more
stringent fbr business users than for IT developers. Which of the following is the BEST action fbr the IS
auditor to take?

options.A: Determine whether this is a policy violation and document it.
options.B: Document the observation as an exception.
options.C: Recommend that all password configuration settings be identical.
options.D: Recommend that logs of IT developer access are reviewed periodically.

justifications.A:
If the policy documents the purpose and approval for different procedures, then an information
systems (IS) auditor only needs to document observations and tests about whether the procedures
are followed.
justifications.B: This condition is not considered an exception if procedures are followed according to approved policies.
justifications.C:
There may be valid reasons fbr these settings to be different; therefore, the auditor does not normally
recommend changes before researching enterprise policies and procedures.
justifications.D:
Although reviewing logs may be a good compensating control, the more important course of action is to
determine if policies are being followed.

questions.question:
An organization is developing a new web-based application to process orders from customers. Which of the
following security measures should be taken to protect this application from hackers?

options.A: Ensure that ports 80 and 443 are blocked at the firewall.
options.B: Inspect file and access permissions on all servers to ensure that all files have read-only access.
options.C: Perform a web application security review.
options.D: Make sure that only the internet protocol (IP) addresses of existing customers are allowed through the

justifications.A:
Port 80 must be open fbr a web application to work, and port 443 must be open for a Secured Hypertext
Transmission Protocol to operate.
justifications.B:
For customer orders to be placed, some data must be saved to the server. No customer orders can be
placed on a read-only server.
justifications.C:
Performing a web application security review is a necessary effort to uncover security
vulnerabilities that can be exploited by hackers.
justifications.D:
Restricting internet protocol (IP) addresses might be appropriate fbr some types of web applications but is
not the best solution because a new customer cannot place an order until the firewall rules were changed
to allow the customer to connect.

questions.question:
Which of the following types of penetration tests simulates a real attack and is used to test incident handling
and response capability of the target?

justifications.A:
Blind testing is also known as black-box testing. This refers to a test where the penetration tester is not
given any information and is forced to rely on publicly available information. This test simulates a real
attack, except that the target organization is aware of the test being conducted.
justifications.B:
Targeted testing is also known as white-box testing. This refers to a test where the penetration tester is
provided with information and the target organization is also aware of the testing activities. In some cases,
the tester is also provided with a limited-privilege account to be used as a starting point.
justifications.C:
Double-blind testing is also known as zero-knowledge testing. This refers to a test where the
penetration tester is not given any information and the target organization is not given any warning
—both parties are blind to the test. This is the best scenario for testing response capability because
the target will react as if the attack were real.
justifications.D:
External testing refers to a test where an external penetration tester launches attacks on the targefs
network perimeter from outside the target network (typically from the Internet).
386 C/SA ® Official Questions, Answers & Explanations Manual 13th Edition
©ISACA. All Rights Reserved.

questions.question:
An organization requests that an information systems (IS) auditor provide a recommendation to enhance
the security and reliability of its Voice-over Internet Protocol (VblP) system and data traffic. Which of the
following meets this objective?

options.A: VblP infrastructure needs to be segregated using virtual local area networks.
options.B: Buffers need to be introduced at the VblP endpoints.
options.C: Ensure that end-to-end encryption is enabled in the VoIP system.
options.D: Ensure that emergency backup power is available for all parts of the VblP infrastructure.

justifications.A:
Segregating the Voice-over Internet Protocol (VoIP) traffic using virtual local area networks
(VLANs) best protects the VoIP infrastructure from network-based attacks, potential
eavesdropping and network traffic issues (which helps to ensure uptime).
justifications.B: The use of packet buffers at VblP endpoints is a method to maintain call quality, not a security method.
justifications.C:
Encryption is used when VblP calls use the Internet (not the local area network (LAN)) for transport
because the assumption is that the physical security of the building and the Ethernet switch and VLAN
security are adequate.
justifications.D:
The design of the network and the proper implementation of VLANs are more critical than ensuring that
all devices are protected by emergency power.
387

questions.question:
During a review of intrusion detection logs, an information systems (IS) auditor notices traffic coming from
the Internet, which appears to originate from the internal internet protocol (IP) address of the enterprise
payroll server. Which of the following malicious activities would MOST likely cause this type of result?

justifications.A:
A denial-of-service (DoS) attack is designed to limit the availability of a resource and is characterized
by a high number of requests that require response from the resource (usually a website). The target
spends so many resources responding to the attack requests that legitimate requests are not serviced*
These attacks are most commonly launched from networks of compromised computers (botnets) and may
involve attacks from multiple computers at once.
justifications.B:
Spoofing is a form of impersonation where one computer tries to take on the identity of another
computer When an attack originates from the external network but uses an internal network
address, the attacker is most likely trying to bypass firewalls and other network security controls
by impersonating (or spoofing) the payroll server's internal network address. By impersonating the
payroll server, the attacker may be able to access sensitive internal resources.
justifications.C:
Port scanning is a reconnaissance technique that is designed to gather information about a target before a
more active attack. Port scanning might be used to determine the internal address of the payroll server but
would not normally create a log entry that indicated external traffic from an internal server address.
justifications.D:
A man-in-the-middle attack is a form of active eavesdropping where the attacker intercepts a
computerized conversation between two parties and then allows the conversation to continue by relaying
the appropriate data to both parties, while simultaneously monitoring the same data passing through the
attacker's conduit. This type of attack does not register as an attack originating from the payroll server,
but, instead, it might be designed to hijack an authorized connection between a workstation and the
payroll server.

questions.question:
An information systems (IS) auditor is reviewing an organization's information security policy, which requires
encryption of all data placed on USB drives. The policy also requires that a specific encryption algorithm be
used. Which of the following algorithms would provide the greatest assurance that data placed on USB drives
is protected from unauthorized disclosure?

justifications.B:
Message digest 5 (MD5) is an algorithm used to generate a one-way hash of data (a fixed-length value)
to test and verify data integrity. MD5 does not encrypt data but puts data through a mathematical process
that cannot be reversed. As a result, MD5 cannot be used to encrypt data on a USB drive.
justifications.C:
Advanced Encryption Standard (AES) provides the strongest encryption of all the choices listed
and provides the greatest assurance that data are protected. Recovering data encrypted with AES
is considered computationally infeasible; therefore, AES is the best choice for encrypting sensitive
data.
justifications.D:
secure shell (SSH) is a protocol that is used to establish a secure, encrypted, command-line shell session,
typically fbr remote logon. Although SSH encrypts data transmitted during a session, SSH cannot encrypt
data at rest, including data on USB drives. As a result, SSH is not appropriate fbr this scenario.

questions.question:
During an information systems (IS) audit of a global enterprise, the IS auditor discovers that the enterprise
uses Vbice-over Internet Protocol as the sole means of voice connectivity among all offices. Which of
the following presents the MOST significant risk for the enterprise's Vbice-over Internet Protocol (VblP)
infrastructure?

justifications.A:
The use of Vbice-over Internet Protocol does not introduce any unique risk with respect to equipment
failure, and redundancy can be used to address network failure.
justifications.B:
A distributed denial of service (DDoS) attack would potentially disrupt the enterprise's ability to
communicate among its offices and have the highest impact. In a traditional voice network, a DDoS
attack would only affect the data network, not voice communications.
justifications.C:
Toll fraud occurs when someone compromises the phone system and makes unauthorized long-distance
calls. Although toll fraud may cost the business money, the more severe risk is the disruption of service.
justifications.D:
Social engineering, which involves gathering sensitive information to launch an attack, can be exercised
over any kind of telephony.
389

questions.question:
Which of the following is the MOST effective control for restricting access to unauthorized Internet sites in
an enterprise?

options.A: Routing outbound Internet traffic through a content-filtering proxy server
options.B: Routing inbound Internet traffic through a reverse proxy server
options.C: Implementing a firewall with appropriate access rules
options.D: Deploying client software utilities that block inappropriate content

justifications.A:
A content-filtering proxy server will effectively monitor user access to Internet sites and block
access to unauthorized web sites.
justifications.B:
When a client web browser makes a request to an Internet site, those requests are outbound from the
enterprise network. A reverse proxy server is used to allow secure remote connection to an enterprise site,
not to control employee web access.
justifications.C:
A firewall exists to block unauthorized inbound and outbound network traffic. Some firewalls can be
used to block or allow access to certain sites, but the term firewall is generic—there are many types of
firewalls, and this is not the best answer.
justifications.D:
Although client software utilities do exist to block inappropriate content, installing and maintaining
additional software on a large number of PCs is less effective than controlling the access from a single,
centralized proxy server.

questions.question:
An internal audit function is reviewing an internally developed common gateway interface script fbr a web
application. The information systems (IS) auditor discovers that the script was not reviewed and tested by the
quality control function. Which of the following types of risk is of GREATEST concern?

justifications.A:
Although untested common gateway interface (CGI) can cause the end-user web application to be
compromised, this is not likely to make the system unavailable to other users.
justifications.B: Untested CGI scripts do not inherently lead to malware exposures.
justifications.C:
Untested CGIs can have security weaknesses that allow unauthorized access to private systems
because CGIs are typically executed on publicly available Internet servers.
justifications.D:
Although untested CGIs can cause the end-user web application to be compromised, this is not likely to
significantly impact system integrity.

questions.question:
An information systems (IS) auditor is conducting a postimplementation review of an enterprise's network.
Which of the following findings would be of MOST concern?

options.A: Wireless mobile devices are not password-protected.
options.B: Default passwords are not changed when installing network devices.
options.C: An outbound web proxy does not exist.
options.D: All communication links do not use encryption.

justifications.A:
Although mobile devices that are not password-protected are a risk, this is not as significant as unsecured
network devices.
justifications.B:
The most significant risk in this case is that the factory default passwords are not changed
on critical network equipment This can allow anyone to change the configurations of network
equipment.
justifications.C: The use of a web proxy is a good practice but may not be required depending on the enterprise.
justifications.D:
Encryption is a good control for data security but is not appropriate to use for all communication links due
to cost and complexity.

questions.question:
An information systems (IS) auditor is reviewing a third-party agreement fbr a new cloud-based accounting
service provider. Which of the following considerations is the MOST important with regard to the privacy of
accounting data?

justifications.A: Data retention, backup and recovery are important controls; however, they do not guarantee data privacy.
justifications.B:
When reviewing a third-party agreement, the most important consideration regarding the privacy
of the data is the clause concerning the return or secure destruction of information at the end of the
contract.
justifications.C:
Network and intrusion detection are helpful when securing the data, but on their own, they do not
guarantee data privacy stored at a third-party provider.
justifications.D:
A patch management process helps secure servers and may prohibit unauthorized disclosure of data;
however, it does not affect the privacy of the data.
391

questions.question: Which of the following is the MOST effective control when granting temporary access to vendors?

options.A: Vendor access corresponds to the service level agreement (SLA).
options.B: User accounts are created with expiration dates and are based on services provided.
options.C: Administrator access is provided fbr a limited period.
options.D: User IDs are deleted when the work is completed.

justifications.A:
The service level agreement (SLA) may have a provision for providing access, but this is not a control; it
would merely define the need fbr access.
justifications.B:
The most effective control is to ensure that the granting of temporary access is based on services to
be provided and that there is an expiration date (automated is best) associated with each unique ID.
The use of an identity management system enforces temporary and permanent access fbr users, at
the same time ensuring proper accounting of their activities.
justifications.C:
Vendors may require administrator access fbr a limited period during the time of service. However, it
is important to ensure that the level of access granted is set according to least privilege and that access
during this period is monitored.
justifications.D:
The use of an identity management system enforces temporary and permanent access fbr users, at
the same time ensuring proper accounting of their activities.

questions.question:
During a logical access controls review, an infbrmation systems (IS) auditor observes that user accounts are
shared. The GREATEST risk resulting from this situation is that:

options.A: an unauthorized user may use the ID to gain access.
options.B: user access management is time consuming.
options.D: user accountability may not be established.

justifications.A:
The ability of unauthorized users to use a shared ID is more likely than to use an individual ID—but the
misuse of another person's ID is always a risk.
justifications.B: Using shared IDs does not pose an increased risk due to the work required for managing access.
justifications.C: Shared user IDs do not necessarily have easily guessed passwords.
justifications.D:
The use of a user ID by more than one individual precludes knowing who used that ID to access a
system; therefore, it is impossible to hold anyone accountable.
392 CISA ® Official Questions, Answers & Explanations Manual 13th Edition
©ISACA. All Rights Reserved.

questions.question:
An information systems (IS) auditor is assessing a biometric system used to protect physical access to a data
center containing regulated data. Which of the following observations is the GREATEST concern to the
auditor?

options.A:
Administrative access to the biometric scanners or the access control system is permitted over a virtual
private network.
options.B: Biometric scanners are not installed in restricted areas.
options.C:
Data transmitted between the biometric scanners and the access control system do not use a securely
encrypted tunnel.
options.D: Biometric system risk analysis was last conducted three years ago.

justifications.A:
Generally, virtual private network software provides a secure tunnel so that remote administration
functions can be performed. This is not a concern.
justifications.B:
Biometric scanners are best located in restricted areas to prevent tampering, but video surveillance is an
acceptable mitigating control. The greatest concern is the lack of a securely encrypted tunnel between the
scanners and the access control system.
justifications.C:
Data transmitted between the biometric scanners and the access control system should use a
securely encrypted tunnel to protect the confidentiality of the biometric data.
justifications.D:
The biometric risk analysis should be reperformed periodically, but an analysis performed three years ago
is not necessarily a cause fbr concern.

questions.question:
When auditing a role-based access control system, the information systems (IS) auditor noticed that some IT
security employees have system administrator privileges on some servers, which allows them to modify or
delete transaction logs. Which would be the BEST recommendation that the IS auditor should make?

options.A: Ensure that these employees are adequately supervised.
options.B: Ensure that backups of the transaction logs are retained.
options.C: Implement controls to detect the changes.
options.D: Write transaction logs in real time to write once and read many (WORM) drives.

justifications.A:
IT security employees cannot be supervised in the traditional sense unless the supervisor were to monitor
each keystroke entered on a workstation, which is not a realistic option.
justifications.B:
Retaining backups of the transaction logs does not prevent the files from unauthorized modification prior
to backup.
justifications.C:
The log files themselves are the main evidence that an unauthorized change was made, which is a
sufficient detective control. Protecting the log files from modification requires preventive controls, such
as securely writing the logs.
justifications.D:
Allowing IT security employees access to transaction logs is often unavoidable because having
system administrator privileges is required for them to do their job. The best control in this case, to
avoid unauthorized modifications of transaction logs, is to write the transaction logs to write once
and read many (WORM) drive media in real time. It is important to note that simply backing up
the transaction logs to drives is not adequate because data can be modified prior (typically at night)
to the daily backup job execution.
393
CISA ® Official Questions, Answers & Explanations Manual 13th Edition
©ISACA. All Rights Reserved.

questions.question:
During an information systems (IS) audit of a bank, the IS auditor is assessing whether the enterprise properly
manages staff member access to the operating system. The IS auditor should determine whether the enterprise
performs:

options.A: periodic review of user activity logs.
options.B: verification of user authorization at the field level.
options.C: review of data communication access activity logs.
options.D: periodic review of changing data files.

justifications.A:
General operating system access control functions include logging user activities, events, etc.
Reviewing these logs may identify users performing activities that should not have been permitted.
justifications.B:
Verification of user authorization at the field level is a database- and/or an application-level access control
function and not applicable to an operating system.
justifications.C: Review of data communication access activity logs is a network control feature.
justifications.D: Periodic review of changing data files is related to a change control process.

questions.question:
An information systems (IS) auditor performing an audit of the newly installed Voice-over Internet Protocol
system is inspecting the wiring closets on each floor of a building. What would be the GREATEST concern?

options.A: The local area network (LAN) switches are not connected to uninterruptible power supply units.
options.B: Network cabling is disorganized and not properly labeled.
options.C: The telephones are using the same cable used fbr LAN connections.
options.D: The wiring closet also contains power lines and breaker panels.

justifications.A:
Voice-over Internet Protocol (VoIP) telephone systems use standard network cabling and typically
each telephone gets power over the network cable (power over Ethernet) from the wiring closet
where the network switch is installed. If the local area network switches do not have backup power;
the phones will lose power if there is a utility interruption and potentially not be able to make
emergency calls.
justifications.B:
Although improper cabling can create reliability issues, the more critical issue in this case is the lack of
power protection.
justifications.C:
An advantage of VoIP telephone systems is that they use the same cable types and network switches as
standard PC network connections. Therefore, this is not a concern.
justifications.D:
If the power and telephone equipment are separated, this is not a significant risk.
394 CISA ® Official Questions, Answers & Explanations Manual 13th Edition
©ISACA. All Rights Reserved.

questions.question:
When reviewing an enterprise's logical access security to its remote systems, which of the following would be
of GREATEST concern to an information systems (IS) auditor?

justifications.A:
The passwords should not be shared, but this is less important than ensuring that the password files are
encrypted.
justifications.B:
When evaluating the technical aspects of logical security, unencrypted passwords represent the
greatest risk because it is assumed that remote access is over an untrusted network where
passwords can be discovered.
justifications.C:
Checking fbr the redundancy of logon IDs is essential but is less important than ensuring that the
passwords are encrypted.
justifications.D:
There may be business requirements, such as the use of contractors that requires them to have system
access, so this may not be a concern.

questions.question:
During an information systems (IS) risk assessment of a health care organization regarding protected health
information (PHI), an IS auditor interviews IS management. Which of the following findings from the
interviews would be of MOST concern to the IS auditor?

options.A: The organization does not encrypt all of its outgoing email messages.
options.B: Staff have to type "[PHI]" in the subject field of email messages to be encrypted.
options.C: An individuaPs computer screen saver function is disabled.
options.D: Server configuration requires the user to change the password annually.

justifications.A: Encrypting all outgoing email is expensive and is not common business practice.
justifications.B:
There will always be human-error risk that staff members forget to type certain words in the
subject field. The organization should have automated encryption set up for outgoing email for
employees working with protected health information (PHI) to protect sensitive information.
justifications.C:
Disabling the screen saver function increases the risk that sensitive data can be exposed to other
employees; however, the risk is not as great as exposing the data to unauthorized individuals outside
the organization.
justifications.D:
Although changing the password annually is a concern, the risk is not as great as exposing the data to
unauthorized individuals outside the organization.
395
CISA ® Official Questions, Answers & Explanations Manual 13th Edition

questions.question: Which of the following is the responsibility of information asset owners?

options.A: Implementation of information security within applications
options.B: Assignment of criticality levels to data
options.C: Implementation of access rules to data and programs
options.D: Provision of physical and logical security for data

justifications.A:
Implementation of information security within an application is the responsibility of the data custodians
based on the requirements set by the data owner.
justifications.B: It is the responsibility of owners to define the criticality (and sensitivity) levels of information assets.
justifications.C:
Implementation of access rules is a responsibility of data custodians based on the requirements set by the
data owner.
justifications.D: Provision of physical and logical security for data is the responsibility of the security administrator.

questions.question:
An information systems (IS) auditor reviewing a network log discovers that an employee ran elevated
commands on their PC by invoking the task scheduler to launch restricted applications. This is an example of
what type of attack?

justifications.A:
A race condition exploit involves the timing of two events and an action that causes one event to happen
later than expected. The scenario given is not an example of a race condition exploit.
justifications.B:
A privilege escalation attack obtains higher-level system authority by various methods. In this
example, the task scheduler service runs with administrator permissions, and a security flaw allows
programs launched by the scheduler to run at the same permission level.
justifications.C:
Buffer overflows involve applications of actions that take advantage of a defect in the way an application
or system uses memory. By overloading the memory storage mechanism, the system will perform in
unexpected ways. The scenario given is not an example of a buffer overflow exploit.
justifications.D:
Impersonation attacks involve an error in the identification of a privileged user. The scenario given is not
an example of this exploit.

©ISACA. All Rights Reserved.

questions.question:
An information systems (IS) auditor is reviewing access controls fbr a manufacturing organization. During the
review, the IS auditor discovers that data owners can change access controls fbr a low-risk application. The
BEST course of action fbr the IS auditor is to:

options.A: recommend that mandatory access control be implemented.
options.B: report this as a finding to upper management
options.C: report this to the data owners to determine whether it is an exception.
options.D: not report this issue because discretionary access controls are in place.

justifications.A:
Recommending mandatory access control is not correct because it is more appropriate fbr data owners to
have discretionary access control (DAC) in a low-risk application.
justifications.B: The use of DAC may not be an exception and, until confirmed, should not be reported as an issue.
justifications.C:
Although an information systems (IS) auditor may consult with data owners regarding whether this access
is allowed normally, the IS auditor should not rely on the auditee to determine whether this is an issue.
justifications.D:
DAC allows data owners to modify access, which is a normal procedure and is a characteristic of
DAC.

questions.question: Electromagnetic emissions from a terminal represent a risk because they:

options.A: can damage or erase nearby storage media.
options.C: can have adverse health effects on personnel.

justifications.A:
Although a strong magnetic field can erase certain storage media, normally terminals are designed to limit
these emissions; therefore, this is not normally a concern.
justifications.B: Electromagnetic emissions should not cause disruption of central processing units.
justifications.C: Most electromagnetic emissions are low level and do not pose a significant health risk.
justifications.D:
Emissions can be detected by sophisticated equipment and displayed, thus giving unauthorized
persons access to data. TEMPEST is a term referring to the investigation and study of
compromising emanations of unintentional intelligence-bearing signals that, if intercepted and
analyzed, may reveal their contents.

questions.question: Security administration procedures require read-only access to:

justifications.A:
Security administration procedures require write access to access control tables to manage and update the
privileges according to authorized business requirements.
justifications.B:
Security administration procedures require read-only access to security log files to ensure that, once
generated, the logs are not modified. Logs provide evidence and track suspicious transactions and
activities.
justifications.C:
Logging options require write access to allow the administrator to update the way the transactions and
user activities are monitored, captured, stored, processed and reported.
justifications.D:
The security administrator is often responsible fbr user-facing issues, such as managing user roles,
profiles and settings. This requires the administrator to have more than read-only access.

questions.question: The FIRST step in data classification is to:

Data classiflcation is necessary to deHne access rules based on a need-to-do and need-to-know basis.
The data owner is responsible for defining the access rules; therefore, establishing ownership is the

justifications.B:

questions.question: Which stage of a biometrics system operation should the information systems (IS) auditor review FIRST?

justifications.A:
The users must first be enrolled to use a biometric device; therefore, the information systems (IS)
auditor should review this stage first.
justifications.B:
The device captures a physical or behavioral image of the human, identifies the unique features and uses

processes.
justifications.C: A user applying fbr access will be verified against the stored enrolled value.

questions.question: A hacker can obtain passwords without the use of computer tools or programs through the technique of:

justifications.A:
Social engineering is based on the divulgence of private information through dialogues, interviews,

justifications.B: A sniffer is a computer tool to monitor the traffic in networks.
justifications.C: Back doors are computer programs left by hackers to exploit vulnerabilities.
justifications.D:
Trojan horses are computer programs that pretend to supplant a real program; thus, the functionality of the
program is not authorized and is usually malicious in nature.

questions.question: The reliability of an application system's audit trail may be questionable if:

options.A: user IDs are recorded in the audit trail.
options.B: the security administrator has read-only rights to the audit file.
options.C: date and time stamps are recorded when an action occurs.
options.D: users can amend audit trail records when correcting system errors.

justifications.B: Restricting the administrator to read-only access will protect the audit file from alteration.
justifications.C:

D・ An audit trail is not effective if the details in it can be amended.

questions.question:
While conducting an audit, an information systems (IS) auditor detects the presence of a virus. What should
be the IS auditor's NEXT step?

options.B: Clear the virus from the network.

justifications.A:
Observing the response mechanism should be done after informing appropriate personnel. This enables
an information systems (IS) auditor to examine the actual workability and effectiveness of the response
system.
justifications.B: The IS auditor is neither authorized nor capable in most cases of removing the virus from the network.
justifications.C:
The first thing an IS auditor should do after detecting the virus is to alert the organization to its
presence, then wait for their response.
justifications.D:
An IS auditor should not make changes to the system being audited; ensuring the deletion of the virus is a
management responsibility.

questions.question: The implementation of access controls FIRST requires:

options.A: a classification of information systems (IS) resources.
options.C: the creation of an access control list.

justifications.A:
The first step in implementing access controls is an inventory of information systems (IS) resources,
which is the basis fbr classification.
justifications.B: Labeling resources cannot be done without first determining the resources9 classifications.
justifications.C: The access control list is not done without a meaningful classification of resources.
justifications.D:
The first step in implementing access controls is an inventory of IS resources, which is the basis for
establishing ownership and classification.

questions.question: Which of the following is an example of the defense in-depth security principle?

options.A: Using two firewalls to consecutively check the incoming network traffic
options.B: Using a firewall as well as logical access controls on the hosts to control incoming network traffic
options.C: Lack of physical signs on the outside of a computer center building
options.D: Using two firewalls in parallel to check different types of incoming traffic

justifications.A:
Use of two firewalls does not represent an effective defense in-depth strategy because the same attack
can circumvent both devices. By using two different products, the probability of both products having the
same vulnerabilities is diminished.
justifications.B:
Defense in-depth means using different security mechanisms that back up each other When
network traffic passes the firewall unintentionally, the logical access controls form a second line
of defense.
justifications.C:
Having no physical signs on the outside of a computer center building is a single security measure known
as security by obscurity.
justifications.D:
Using two firewalls in parallel to check different types of incoming traffic provides redundancy but is
only a single security mechanism and, therefore, no different than having a single firewall checking all
traffic.

questions.question: Which of the following is the BEST access control procedure?

options.A: The data owner formally authorizes access and an administrator implements the user authorization tables.
options.B: Authorized staff implements the user authorization tables and the data owner approves them.
options.C:
The data owner and an information systems (IS) manager jointly create and update the user authorization
tables.
options.D: The data owner creates and updates the user authorization tables.

justifications.A:
The data owner holds the privilege and responsibility for formally establishing the access rights. An
information systems (IS) administrator should then implement or update user authorization tables
at the direction of the owner,
justifications.B:
The owner sets the rules and conditions fbr access. It is best to obtain approval before implementing the
tables.
justifications.C:
The data owner may consult with the IS manager to set out access control rules, but the responsibility fbr
appropriate access remains with the data owner. The IT department should set up the access control tables
at the direction of the owner.
justifications.D:
The data owner does not usually manage updates to the authorization tables.

questions.question: Which of the following MOST effectively reduces social engineering incidents?

justifications.A:
Social engineering exploits human nature and weaknesses to obtain information and access
privileges. By increasing employee awareness of security issues, it is possible to reduce the number
of successful social engineering incidents.
justifications.B:
In most cases, social engineering incidents do not require the physical presence of the intruder. Therefore,
increased physical security measures would not prevent the incident.
justifications.C:
An email monitoring policy informs users that all email in the organization is subject to monitoring; it
does not protect the users from potential security incidents and intruders.
justifications.D: Intrusion detection systems (IDSs) are used to detect irregular or abnormal traffic patterns.

questions.question:
An information security policy stating that "a fixed time duration of inactivity must initiate a password-
enabled screensaver" addresses which of the following attack methods?

justifications.A:
Piggybacking refers to unauthorized persons following, either physically or virtually, authorized persons
into restricted areas. Initiating a screensaver that requires user to reenter the password prevents someone
from tailgating an authorized person.
justifications.B:
This policy only refers to the user's computer, not dumpster diving (looking through the organization's
trash for valuable information).
justifications.C:
Shoulder surHng refers to observing a user while entering/viewing sensitive data on the screen. This
may enable the observer to obtain login information or other sensitive information.
justifications.D:
Impersonation refers to someone acting as an employee in an attempt to retrieve desired information.

questions.question:
To ensure compliance with a security policy requiring that passwords be a combination of letters and numbers,
an information systems (IS) auditor should recommend that:

options.C: an automated password management tool be used.

justifications.A: The policy is appropriate and does not require change. Changing the policy would not ensure compliance.
justifications.B:
Having a requirement to periodically change passwords is good practice and should be in the password
policy.
justifications.C:
The use of an automated password management tool is a preventive control measure. The software
prevents repetition (semantic) and enforces syntactic rules, thus making the passwords robust. It
also provides a method for ensuring frequent changes and prevents the same user from reusing
his/her old password for a designated period of time.
justifications.D: Security awareness training does not enforce compliance.

questions.question:
An information systems (IS) auditor reviewing digital rights management applications should expect to find
an extensive use for which of the following technologies?

justifications.A:
Digitalized signatures are the scans of a signature (not the same as a digital signature) and not related to
digital rights management.
justifications.B:
Hashing creates a message hash or digest, which is used to ensure the integrity of the message; it is
usually considered a part of cryptography.
justifications.C:
Parsing is the process of splitting up a continuous stream of characters for analytical purposes and is
widely applied in the design of programming languages or in data entry editing.
justifications.D:
Steganography is a technique for concealing the existence of messages or information within
another message. An increasingly important steganographic technique is digital watermarking,
which hides data within data (e.g., by encoding rights information in a picture or music file without
altering the picture or music's perceivable aesthetic qualities).

questions.question:
The information security policy that states “each individual must have his/her badge read at every controlled
door” addresses which of the following attack methods?

justifications.A:
Piggybacking refers to unauthorized persons following authorized persons, either physically or
virtually, into restricted areas. This policy addresses the polite behavior problem of holding doors
open for a stranger. If every employee must have their badge read at every controlled door, no
unauthorized person can enter the sensitive area.
justifications.B:
Shoulder surfing (looking over the shoulder of a person to view sensitive information on a screen or desk)
would not be prevented by the implementation of this policy.
justifications.C:
Dumpster diving, looking through organization's trash fbr valuable information, can be done outside the
enterprise's physical perimeter; therefore, this policy would not address this attack method.
justifications.D:
Impersonation refers to an unauthorized person acting as an employee, trying to retrieve the
desired information. Some forms of social engineering attacks can join an impersonation attack and
piggybacking, but this information security policy does not address the impersonation attack.

questions.question: The MOST important difference between hashing and encryption is that hashing:

options.B: output is the same length as the original message.
options.C: is concerned with integrity and security.
options.D: is the same at the sending and receiving end.

justifications.A:
Hashing works one way—by applying a hashing algorithm to a message, a message hash/digest is
created. If the same hashing algorithm is applied to the message digest, it will not result in the
original message. Therefore, hashing is irreversible, while encryption is reversible. This is the basic
difference between hashing and encryption.
justifications.B:
Hashing creates a fixed-length output that is usually smaller than the original message, and encryption
creates an output that is usually the same length as the original message.
justifications.C:
Hashing is used to verify the integrity of the message and does not address security. The same hashing
algorithm is used at the sending and receiving ends to generate and verify the message hash/digest.
justifications.D:
Encryption may use different keys or a reverse process at the sending and receiving ends to encrypt and
decrypt.

questions.question: Which of the following cryptography options increases overhead/cost?

options.A: The encryption is symmetric rather than asymmetric.
options.B: A long asymmetric encryption key is used.
options.C: The hash is encrypted rather than the message.

justifications.A: An asymmetric algorithm requires more processing time than symmetric algorithms.
justifications.B:
Computer processing time is increased for longer asymmetric encryption keys, and the increase
may be disproportionate. For example, one benchmark showed that doubling the length of an RSA
key from 512 bits to 1,024 bits caused the decrypt time to increase nearly six-fold.
justifications.C:
A hash is usually shorter than the original message; therefore, a smaller overhead is required if the hash is
encrypted rather than the message.
justifications.D:
A secret key, used as a symmetric encryption key, is generally small and used fbr the purpose of
encrypting user data.

questions.question: The MOST important factor in planning a black box penetration test is:

options.A: the documentation of the planned testing procedure.
options.B: a realistic evaluation of the environment architecture to determine scope.
options.C: knowledge by the management staff of the client organization.
options.D: scheduling and deciding on the timed length of the test.

justifications.A:
A penetration test should be carefully planned and executed, but the most important factor is proper
approvals.
justifications.B: In a black box penetration test, the environment is not known to the testing organization.
justifications.C:
Black box penetration testing assumes no prior knowledge of the infrastructure to be tested. Testers
simulate an attack from someone who is unfamiliar with the system. It is important to have
management knowledge of the proceedings so that if the test is identified by the monitoring systems,
the legality of the actions can be determined quickly.
justifications.D:
A test must be scheduled to minimize the risk of affecting critical operations; however, this is part of
working with the management of the organization.

questions.question:
An enterprise allows fbr the use of universal serial bus drives to transfer operational data between offices.
Which of the following is the GREATEST risk associated with the use of these devices?

options.C: Use of the devices for personal purposes
options.D: Introduction of malware into the network

justifications.A: Although this is a risk, theft of an unencrypted device is a greater risk.
justifications.B:
Because USB drives tend to be small, they are susceptible to theft or loss. This represents the
greatest risk to the enterprise.
justifications.C:
Use of USB drives fbr personal purposes is a violation of enterprise policy; however, this is not the
greatest risk.
justifications.D:
Good general IT controls include the scanning of USB drives fbr malware when they are inserted in a
computer. The risk of malware in an otherwise robust environment is not as great as the risk of loss or
theft.
407

questions.question:
When performing a computer forensic investigation, in regard to the evidence gathered, an information
systems (IS) auditor should be MOST concerned with:

justifications.A: Analysis is important but not the primary concern related to evidence in a forensic investigation.
justifications.B: Evaluation is important but not the primary concern related to evidence in a forensic investigation.
justifications.C:
Preservation and documentation of evidence for review by law enforcement and judicial authorities
are of primary concern when investigating. Failure to properly preserve the evidence can
jeopardize the admissibility of the evidence in legal proceedings.
justifications.D:
Disclosure is important but not of primary concern to the information systems (IS) auditor in a forensic
investigation.

questions.question: A certificate (certification) authority (CA) can delegate the processes of:

options.A: revocation and suspension of a subscriber's certificate.
options.B: generation and distribution of the CA public key.
options.C: establishing a link between the requesting entity and its public key.

justifications.A:
Revocation and suspension of the subscriber certificate are functions of the subscriber certificate life
cycle management, which the certificate (certification) authority (CA) must perform.
justifications.B:
Generation and distribution of the CA public key is a part of the CA key life cycle management process
and, as such, cannot be delegated.
justifications.C:
Establishing a link between the requesting entity and its public key is a function of a registration
authority. This may or may not be performed by a CA; therefore, this function can be delegated.
justifications.D:
Issuance and distribution of the subscriber certificate are functions of the subscriber certificate life cycle
management, which the CA must perform.
408 CISA ® Official Questions, Answers & Explanations Manual 13th Edition
©ISACA. All Rights Reserved.

questions.question: Which of the following results in a denial-of-service (DoS) attack?

justifications.A:
A brute force attack is typically a text attack that exhausts all possible key combinations used against
encryption keys or passwords.
justifications.B:
The use of Ping with a packet size higher than 65 kilobyte (KB) and no fragmentation flag on will
cause a denial of service.
justifications.C:
A leapfrog attack, the act of telneting through one or more hosts to preclude a trace, makes use of user ID
and password information obtained illicitly from one host to compromise another host.
justifications.D:
A negative acknowledgment is a penetration technique that capitalizes on a potential weakness in
an operating system that does not handle asynchronous interrupts properly, leaving the system in an
unprotected state during such interrupts.

questions.question: Which of the following is an advantage of elliptic curve encryption over RSA encryption?

justifications.A:
The main advantage of elliptical curve cryptography (ECC) over RSA encryption is its computation
speed. This is due in part to the use of much smaller keys in the ECC algorithm than in RSA.
justifications.B: Both encryption methods support digital signatures.
justifications.C: Both encryption methods are used fbr public key encryption and distribution.
justifications.D:
Both ECC and RSA offer message integrity controls.
409
